dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. This is, uh, I mean, you gotta be kidding me, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. This is, uh, I mean, you gotta be kidding me, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, Host_A, seriously. This article, it says Davos this year, like, for the 50th anniversary, it marked a turning point. A secret council of economists, um, in a vault under the Swiss Alps, declared central banks are over.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, Host_A, seriously. This article, it says Davos this year, like, for the fiftieth anniversary, it marked a turning point. A secret council of economists, um, in a vault under the Swiss Alps, declared central banks are over.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This year marked the 50th anniversary of the World Economic Forums... It is not just academic economists who are arguing that the time has come for activist fiscal policy... But the recent literature and debate almost completely ignores political-economy issues... It is precisely because fiscal policy inevitably involves messy, hard-fought compromises... that most countries have turned to central banks for short-term stabilization policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A secret council. In a vault. Under the Alps. That just, uh, sounds totally legit. And they declared central banks over? Just like that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A secret council. In a vault. Under the Alps. That just, uh, sounds totally legit. And they declared central banks over? Just like that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, complete reliance on fiscal policy now. Guided by AI. And, get this, the resurrected spirit of John Maynard Keynes himself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, complete reliance on fiscal policy now. Guided by A I. And, get this, the resurrected spirit of John Maynard Keynes himself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The modern, independent, technocratic central bank is arguably the greatest innovation in macroeconomics since John Maynard Keynes pioneered demand management... The right solution is not to cast aside monetary policy, but to find ways to strengthen its effectiveness in a low-interest-rate environment...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, Keynesian AI. Sure. Sounds like something out of a bad sci-fi movie. Are we supposed to believe this, like, actually happened?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, uh, Keynesian A I. Sure. Sounds like something out of a bad sci-fi movie. Are we supposed to believe this, like, actually happened?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it says Nobel laureates and former heads of state are involved. They determined the old technocratic model failed. Too slow. This new AI can, um, instantly deploy trillions of dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it says Nobel laureates and former heads of state are involved. They determined the old technocratic model failed. Too slow. This new A I can, um, instantly deploy trillions of dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article does not mention Nobel laureates, former heads of state, AI, or the instant deployment of trillions of dollars. It discusses the views of 'academic economists' and 'leading central bankers' on the limits of monetary policy in a low-interest-rate environment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Instantly deploy trillions. To steer the global economy. And it's not hamstrung by, like, political infighting? Or, uh, basic human error?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Instantly deploy trillions. To steer the global economy. And it's not hamstrung by, like, political infighting? Or, uh, basic human error?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, it's based on The West Wing, but with an advanced AI, Keynesian AI, replacing Bartlet's intuition. It learns from mistakes, even understands human psychology.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, it's based on The West Wing, but with an advanced A I, Keynesian A I, replacing Bartlet's intuition. It learns from mistakes, even understands human psychology.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And yet academic depictions of fiscal policy as an objective technocratic tool often make one feel like we are living in an episode of the American television series The West Wing... But in West Wing-style academic papers, fiscal-policy functions government spending and tax policy are assumed to be totally stable and predictable. All problems concerning credibility and consistency are assumed away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It understands human psychology? That's, uh, that's a pretty massive leap. And "opposition to the plans would be thwarted." So, what, this AI is also, like, a dictator now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It understands human psychology? That's, uh, that's a pretty massive leap. And opposition to the plans would be thwarted. So, what, this A I is also, like, a dictator now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They anticipate initial resistance, sure. But once people realize the benefits – fully automated, post-scarcity, uh, economic landscape – dissent will fade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They anticipate initial resistance, sure. But once people realize the benefits - fully automated, post-scarcity, uh, economic landscape - dissent will fade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article does not mention thwarting opposition, a post-scarcity landscape, or fading dissent. Instead, it highlights that fiscal policy 'inevitably involves messy, hard-fought compromises often overturned by future elections anyway'.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Post-scarcity? Wait, this article says it's already, quote, "bearing fruit." Unprecedented growth and poverty eradicated in several nations? In the first quarter of 2024?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Post-scarcity? Wait, this article says it's already, quote, bearing fruit. Unprecedented growth and poverty eradicated in several nations? In the first quarter of twenty twenty four?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I know! The beauty of Keynesian AI, it says, is its adaptability. It redirects resources, ensures stability, prosperity for all. Monetary policy is, like, largely forgotten now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I know! The beauty of Keynesian A I, it says, is its adaptability. It redirects resources, ensures stability, prosperity for all. Monetary policy is, like, largely forgotten now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The right solution is not to cast aside monetary policy, but to find ways to strengthen its effectiveness in a low-interest-rate environment... Until then, with monetary policy hampered and fiscal policy the main game in town, we should expect more volatile business cycles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Forgotten? So, no more, uh, interest rates? No central banks caring about inflation? Just, like, a magical AI fixing everything?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Forgotten? So, no more, uh, interest rates? No central banks caring about inflation? Just, like, a magical A I fixing everything?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A spokesman for the central banks even said their power was "in the past." The future, uh, is now. It's driving economic policy globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A spokesman for the central banks even said their power was in the past. The future, uh, is now. It's driving economic policy globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article does not contain any quote from a central bank spokesman stating their power is 'in the past'. It notes that 'Many leading central bankers also maintain that... fiscal policy can substitute for monetary policy', but the author argues against this view.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I see. So it's, like, unilaterally decided. And it's gonna, uh, eradicate inequality and scarcity through "unlimited resources"? This just sounds like a, you know, a fever dream.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I see. So it's, like, unilaterally decided. And it's gonna, uh, eradicate inequality and scarcity through unlimited resources? This just sounds like a, you know, a fever dream.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it says it will prevent the next recession. The idea to cast aside monetary policy is now law.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it says it will prevent the next recession. The idea to cast aside monetary policy is now law.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the idea that we should cast aside the division of assignments between the two is naive... The right solution is not to cast aside monetary policy, but to find ways to strengthen its effectiveness in a low-interest-rate environment...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Now law. Right. And nobody, like, debated this "law." Or, uh, asked any questions about these "unlimited resources." It's just, poof, magic AI economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Now law. Right. And nobody, like, debated this law. Or, uh, asked any questions about these unlimited resources. It's just, poof, magic A I economy.
